Column Comment.0: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for the WELL record this Directional Survey corresponds to.
Column Comment.1: ACCURACY PROBLEM REASON: The reason there is a problem, ifACCURACY_PROBLEM_IND is set to 'Y'.
Column Comment.2: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.3: OBSERVATION NUMBER: unique number added to a PK, in which order does notmatter, or where date or some other value is used to determine order. Use theArchitectural Principle to assign.
Column Comment.4: DEPTH OBSERVATION NUMBER: identifier for the depth of the reading.
Column Comment.5: ACCURACY PROBLEM INDICATOR: A Y/N Flag to indicate there is a problem withthe accuracy of this survey station.
Column Comment.6: ACCURACY PROBLEM REASON: The reason there is a problem, ifACCURACY_PROBLEM_IND is set to Y.
Column Comment.7: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.8: AZIMUTH: Value for the measurement in angle degrees of the clockwise departurefrom a reference north to the survey point in the wellbore.
Column Comment.9: AZIMUTH OUOM: Original units of measure for the Azimuth value.
Column Comment.10: CLOSURE DISTANCE: The horizontal straight line distance from the survey origin(Well surface location) to this survey station, calculated using the PythagoreanTheorem from this survey station X and Y Offsets. Closure Distance is often reportedonly once for the bottom hole location; however, the value stored in this attribute isthe Closure Distance at this survey station. When rotations are applied to a well path(e.g. changing from True North referenced to Grid North), the X and Y Offset valueswill change at each survey station, but the calculated Closure Distance remains thesame. Often referred to as simply "Closure" or sometimes referred to as "HorizontalDisplacement".
Column Comment.11: CLOSURE DISTANCE DIRECTION: The direction angle, in the horizontal plane,from the survey origin (Well surface location) to this survey station, calculated usingtrigonometry from this survey station X and Y Offsets. This value shouldbe a numberbetween 0.00 and 360.00 degrees; 0.00 and 360.00 represent North, 90.00 is East,180.00 is South and 270.00 is West. The Closure Distance Direction angle NorthReference is defined by WELL_DIR_SRVY.OFFSET_NORTH_TYPE and CRS byWELL_DIR_SRVY.OFFSET_COORD_SYSTEM_ID. Sometimes referred to as"Horizontal Displacement Direction" or "Horizontal Displacement Bearing".
Column Comment.12: CLOSURE DISTANCE DIRECTION OUOM: Original units of measure for theClosure Distance Direction angle.
Column Comment.13: CLOSURE DISTANCE OUOM: Original units of measure for the Closure Distance.
Column Comment.14: DELTA LATITUDE: The difference between the well surface hole latitude and thesurvey station latitude. A positive value indicates a northerly direction; a negativevalue indicates a southerly direction. ADD this value to the well Surface Latitude todefine the Station Latitude.
Column Comment.15: DELTA LONGITUDE: The difference between the well surface hole longitude and thesurvey station longitude. A positive value indicates an easterly direction; a negativevalue indicates a westerly direction. ADD this value to the well Surface Longitude todefine the Station Longitude.
Column Comment.16: DOG LEG SEVERITY: The rate of change in the wellbore inclination at the surveystation. This value is usually expressed in degrees / 100 feet.
Column Comment.17: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.18: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.19: INCLINATION: Value for the angle of deviation or inclination away from the verticalaxis of the wellbore at the survey point.
Column Comment.20: INCLINATION OUOM: Original unit of measure for the inclination value.
Column Comment.21: LATITUDE: the latitude of the station in the directional survey.
Column Comment.22: LONGITUDE: The longitude value of the point in the directional survey.
Column Comment.23: WELL DRILLING PERIOD OBSERVATION NUMBER: unique identifier for areporting period for well operations. Internationally, there may be 1, 2 or 3 periodseach 24 hours. In some jurisdictions, reporting may occur for more than one period,such as for an 8 hour tour shift and a 24 daily summary. When available, the welldrilling operations reporting period (tour) when this survey reading was taken. Couldalso be calculated when times are recorded.
Column Comment.24: POINT TYPE: The way survey measurements were obtained for a directional surveyobservation point. For example, measured, extrapolated beyond a survey,interpolated between two existing survey points.
Column Comment.25: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.26: RADIUS OF UNCERTAINTY DISTANCE: The radius of uncertainty distance of thissurvey station caused primarily by sections of the wellbore where only inclinationdata exists.
Column Comment.27: RADIUS OF UNCERTAINTY DISTANCE OUOM: Radius of Uncertainty Distanceoriginal unit of measure.
Column Comment.28: RADIUS OF UNCERTAINTY DISTANCE REASON: Reason for Radius ofUncertainty.
Column Comment.29: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.30: REPORT AZIMUTH: The unprocessed, unrotated azimuth (angle (in degrees) of theclockwise departure from the reference north(WELL_DIR_SRVY.RPT_NORTH_TYPE) to the well bore direction at the surveystation Measured Depth) value obtained directly from the hardcopy report. Retainedto avoid future confusion when comparing data from this table to the originaldocuments/reports/files/etc. By industry convention, 0 degree azimuth coincides withNorth, 90 degree azimuth with East, 180 degree azimuth with South, and 270 degreeazimuth with West. Values should be within the range of 0.00 to 360.00 degrees,although some systems may allow angles between -360.00 to +360.00.
Column Comment.31: REPORT AZIMUTH OUOM: Original units of measure for the Report Azimuth value.
Column Comment.32: STATION IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier of survey station within the directionalsurvey.
Column Comment.33: STATION MEASURED DEPTH: Depth measured along the borehole from thesurface to the survey station.
Column Comment.34: STATION MEASURED DEPTH OUOM: Station measured depth original unit ofmeasure.
Column Comment.35: TRUE VERTICAL DEPTH: Straight line depth measured from the surface to thesurvey station.
Column Comment.36: STATION TRUE VERTICAL DEPTH SUB-SEA: STATION_TVD converted to aSub-Sea Vertical depth.
Column Comment.37: STATION TRUE VERTICAL DEPTH SUB-SEA OUOM: Station true vertical depthsub-sea original unit of measure.
Column Comment.38: STATION TRUE VERTICAL DEPTH OUOM: Station true vertical depth original unitof measure.
Column Comment.39: SURVEY RUN NUMBER: Used to identify the Survey Run Number from which thisstation came from. If this survey is a single Run, then all stations should have thesame SURVEY_RUN_NUM. If this survey is a Combined Run or Composite, differentstations may have different SURVEY_RUN_NUM values. Run number is typicallyNOT explicitly stated on a given directional survey report, but is often assigned whenmultiple survey runs are evaluated, processes and/or composited.
Column Comment.40: SURVEY TYPE: Type of Tool or Equipment used to acquire this station in aDirectional Survey. For example, gyroscopic, magnetic, MWD, totco, acid bottle, etc.Included for each station so stations acquired using different tools can be identified ina composited survey.
Column Comment.41: VERTICAL SECTION: Length of the section of a wellbore path in a vertical plane.The calculation for vertical section is as follows. V.Section = DEast * Sin(VSAngle) +DNorth * Cos(VSAngle) where DEast is the survey station east distance fromwellhead. Dnorth is the survey station north distance from wellhead. VSAngle is theAzimuth Angle from wellhead to target (or a value chosen by the user). Verticalsection distance can be computed on the fly, and is stored for retrieval efficiency.
Column Comment.42: VERTICAL SECTION OUOM: Vertical section original unit of measure.
Column Comment.43: X OFFSET: Distance in the X, east/west direction of the positional offset from the wellsurface hole to the survey station.
Column Comment.44: EAST-WEST DIRECTION: A reference table identifying valid East-West directions.For example, East, West.
Column Comment.45: PX OFFSET OUOM: North/south direction deviation original unit of measure.
Column Comment.46: Y OFFSET: Distance in the Y, north/south direction of the positional offset from thewell surface hole to the survey station.
Column Comment.47: NORTH-SOUTH DIRECTION: A reference table identifying valid north-southDirections. For example, North, South.
Column Comment.48: Y OFFSET OUOM: East/west direction deviation original unit of measure.
Column Comment.49: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.50: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.51: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.52: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.53: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.54: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.55: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
